fields.content:
The Redress of the Past: Historical Pageants in Britain, 1905-2016

The Arts and Humanities Research Council is funding a major project examining historical pageants in twentieth-century Britain.

Twentieth-century Britain was subject to regular bouts of 'pageant fever'. Communities across England, Scotland and Wales staged theatrical re-enactments of events from local and national history with thousands of men, women and children involved as performers, organizers and spectators. This was national costume drama on a grand scale. Over the course of the twentieth century many hundreds of events were mounted by communities and institutions, ranging from small churches and village communities to large cities such as Liverpool and Manchester.

Read more about the project

We need your help!

Do you have any materials relating to historical pageants?

Interested in helping shape the direction of the Historical Pageants website?

GET INVOLVED

fields.introduction:
The Arts and Humanities Research Council is funding a major project examining historical pageants in twentieth-century Britain.

Twentieth-century Britain was subject to regular bouts of 'pageant fever'. Communities across England, Scotland and Wales staged theatrical re-enactments of historical events with thousands of men, women and children involved as performers, organizers and spectators. Over the course of the twentieth century many such events were put on, ranging from small churches and village communities to large cities such as Liverpool and Manchester.

Drawing on oral and written evidence, our project offers key insights into the role of heritage in leisure activities, the interaction between local, national and imperial identities, and the character of community life. Our project will reveal the stories that communities and institutions told about themselves. It will result in a comprehensive database of historical pageants, a major book, articles, and an edited volume of essays situating the British movement in its international context.

A key feature of the project will be a publicly-accessible website. This will include general commentary on the pageant movement, representative images of pageant-related ephemera, and oral testimonies from witnesses to historical pageants. It will enable individual users and local history societies to contribute their own memories and memorabilia.
